question: According to the ALOA Technical Standards, what are the minimum documents required to take over maintenance of a master key system?
option: Key Bitting Array and up-to-date bitting list
up-to-date bitting list and key schematic
key schematic and hardware schedule
hardware schedule and Key Bitting Array

question: If the minimum documents for taking over maintenance are not available, what is an acceptable alternative?
option: any of the above
Reverse engineer the documents by decoding all the keys.
Reverse engineer the documents by decoding all the locks.
Generate a new master key system.
Temporarily single-key required locks, until the documents can be obtained.

question:
Look at the following keying schedule:
100 front door 1AA
101 office A   2AA
102 restroom   3AA
103 janitor    AA
104 office B   4AA
If we need to rekey door 101, what would the new key be called?
option: 5AA
2AA
2AA+
X2AA
2BB

question:
Look at the following keying schedule:
100 front door 1AA
101 office A   2AA
102 restroom   3AA
103 janitor    AA
104 office B   4AA
Which of the following is an example of expanding the master key system?
option: none of the above
cutting a new copy of key 3AA to replace a broken key
rekeying door 102 to 1AA
rekeying door 101 to 2AA(NMK)
replacing a damaged lock on door 101 with a new lock keyed to 2AA

question:
Look at the following keying schedule:
100 front door 1AA
101 office A   2AA
102 restroom   3AA
103 janitor    AA
104 office B   4AA
Which of the following is not an example of expanding the master key system?
option: replacing the lock on 102 with a privacy function
rekeying door 102 to X3AA op by 2AA, 4AA, and AA
rekeying door 101 to 5AA
rekeying door 103 to SKD1

question: Which of the following might make you suspect Shoebox master keying?
option: all of the above
Some change keys have more constants than others
Keys have ten depths but they don't follow parity.
Some of the keys appear to be factory originals.

question: Shoebox master keying is unprofessional because...
option: all of the above
it relies on luck to avoid key interchange.
it uses excessive master pins.
it is expressly forbidden by ANSI/BHMA A156.28 .

question: One way to look at expanind a master key system is that you replace the system with a new system which does what?
option: has new keys and/or locks, and contains all the keys from the previous system
has new keys and/or locks, and contains all the keys currently in use
has exactly the same key bittings as the old system, cut on different key blanks

question: Suppose you take over the maintenance on a master key system and find that one of the locks does not operate with the change key specified in the keying schedule. What is a likely cause of this?
option: any of the above
The keying schedule contains a typo.
The system uses Total Position Progression.
The lock has an empty chamber.

question: Suppose you take over the maintenance on a master key system and find that one of the locks does not operate with any of the change keys on the bitting list. What is a likely cause of this?
option: any of the above
The bitting list is not up-to-date.
The bitting list contains a typo.
The key schematic is inverted.
The lock is cross-keyed.
